Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A carpenter is waiting for you to bring them the next load of lumber so they can continue their work without interruption.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing a text from Mia: “Which night are we having our date? I’m free all week!” I smile, picturing her excitement, but my hands are already rough from hauling lumber since dawn. The foreman’s voice cuts through my thoughts, “Hey, the carpenter’s waiting! We need that lumber now!” I wipe sweat from my brow, feeling the weight of the boards and the weight of her expectations. Mia wants us to pick a night, to finally have that uninterrupted evening together. She’s been patient, always understanding when I’m late or too tired, but I know she’s hoping for more this time. At the same moment, I see the carpenter tapping his foot, tools in hand, waiting for me to keep the job moving. If I slow down, the whole crew feels it. My phone buzzes again in my pocket, but my gloves are caked with dust. I stand there, torn, the demands of the site and the hope in Mia’s message pulling me in opposite directions.
